items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: New Yorkers Shiver as Frigid Air Hits the City
items.abstract: After a couple of very mild winters, New Yorkers may have forgotten how quickly a truly cold day can chill right to the bone, but for the next few days, they will get a reminder.

items.title: Talks in Bus Strike Are Set; City Isn’t Taking Part
items.abstract: Negotiations in the city school bus strike are scheduled to continue next week, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not be there and his administration said it would not become involved.

items.title: Why American Giant Re-Designed Its Web Site
items.abstract: The metrics indicate the company made the right call. (Plus, the company has sold out all of its product.)

items.title: Sun City It’s Not
items.abstract: Some buildings on the Upper West Side are NORCs — naturally occurring retirement communities.

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
items.abstract: The measures would affect low-level offenses such as littering, public urination and public consumption of alcohol, in some cases removing them from the criminal justice system.

items.title: Bloomberg’s Presidential Dreams, and Past Realities
items.abstract: Beyond the precedent set by the fate of previous independent presidential candidates, Michael R. Bloomberg would face other obvious obstacles on the road to the White House.

items.title: Cuomo’s Plan for Financing Affordable Housing Worries City Officials
items.abstract: The governor’s proposal to give New York State more control over funding affordable housing projects, city officials said, would create delays and red tape.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: Ringo Lam, Director of Hong Kong Classic ‘City on Fire,’ Dies at 63
items.abstract: He achieved renown with a string of crime dramas, including a 1987 thriller that influenced Quentin Tarantino’s “Reservoir Dogs.”

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: The Met Opera Has a Gay Conductor. Yes, That Matters.
items.abstract: Openly gay performing arts leaders are still rare. So it was a breath of fresh air to chat about coming out and Celine Dion with Yannick Nézet-Séguin and his partner.

items.title: To Save East River Park, the City Intends to Bury It
items.abstract: A plan to protect the Lower East Side from flooding was just rejected by the city, replaced with a drastic revision that costs twice as much but does not disrupt traffic.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: As Omicron Infects Workers, Subway Service Suffers
items.abstract: With coronavirus cases surging in New York, about 21 percent of subway operators and conductors were absent this week, causing suspensions on three lines and changed schedules on others.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.

items.title: Manchester City, Chelsea and Competing With Perfection
items.abstract: Pep Guardiola’s ideas and his teams have changed the way England views the game. The danger is that those changes affect perceptions of what qualifies as success.
